div.p: 1. V:30. Sunday.

Mr Fessenden, a Tutor at Cambridge, preached for Mr Whitney—this morning from Ephesians 4:1. “I therefore, the prisoner of the Lord, beseech you that ye walk worthy of the vocation wherewith ye are called.”— Mr Whitney himself administered the communion, of which I for the first time in my life partook. The form of admission to the Church was simple— Before commencing the service Mr Whitney said that the persons who had expressed their wish to join in the communion might present themselves, upon which each of us rose in his or her place, and he reminded us of the engagements implied in the participation of this rite—a sincere belief in the divine Mission of Christ, and a fixed purpose of living according to the rules of his Gospel.— He then proceeded with the solemnity, which was over in about half an hour. Mr Fessenden preached again in the afternoon from Daniel 6.10. “Now when Daniel knew that the writing was signed, he went into the house; and his windows being open in his chamber towards Jerusalem, he kneeled upon his knees three times a day, and prayed, and gave thanks before his God, as he did aforetime.” This discourse was more elaborate than that of the morning: very well written; and closing with a passage really eloquent— It was upon the perseverance of pious Men in their religious sentiments under persecution— After the service, Mr Quincy called upon me, and I communicated to him all the papers I had been preparing for the Settlement of my father’s Estate; which he approved— But it will yet take two or three days to complete them— He agreed to come out from Boston on Wednesday Evening and execute them all; and then to go with me on Thursday Morning, with the account to the judge of Probate at Dedham. I have been engaged without intermission many days in the preparation of these papers, and have found the necessity of changing several after they had been written and copied— I have purchased more than four fifths of my father’s Estate, which I hope will afford an asylum to my last days. My Son John came out from Boston, and returned again in the Evening. He began the packing up of Chests with papers, to be deposited in the vaults of the Branch Bank of the United States at Boston— I propose to place them all in six Chests painted blue, with the initials of my name upon their lids; and numbered. They will contain the papers of my father and mother; and my own of a date preceding my Mission to Russia in 1809. I have not yet had an hour of time to examine my father’s papers. General H. A. S. Dearborn came from Roxbury, and spent an hour of the Evening with me— I wrote a Letter to Mrs De Wint, and one to Mrs Johnson of Utica, to be signed by the Executors— My brother has also much occupied in copying the Papers.

My Son George, went into Boston in the Stage. Mrs Clark took her daughter Susan to Cambridge and placed her at Mrs Dana’s boarding School. She returned through Boston this Evening. Deacon Spear and Captain John Whitney came, and with my Son John who came out from Boston, they settled the accounts of the last weeks Sales of furniture and farming Stock— Captain Whitney hired the Pew N. 1. at ten dollars for one year from this time— I continued the drafting of papers for the settlement of the Estate, and John, the packing of the papers of my father and mother, in the Chests to be sent to Boston. So much progress was made in this that I desired John, upon his return to Boston to see Mr Quincy and request him to come out and execute the Deeds to-morrow Evening; or early Wednesday Morning: so that we may return our Account to the judge of Probate in Dedham on Wednesday Mrs Baxter came to solicit influence for the appointment of her Son, as a Midshipman in the Navy; for which I invited her to address an application to the Secretary of the Navy— Mr Daniel Greenleaf came and gave me a written estimate of a reasonable rent for this farm, which with all the Salt-marsh he makes 450 dollars a year exclusive of the House and Garden. The whole farm will cost me 22000 dollars and will not yield 3 per cent interest by the year— But the gradual increase in the value of Lands will probably be an equivalent for the other 3 per Cent— I called this afternoon at Mr Whitney the Minister, and returned him his old Church Record Book. I asked the Copy of his Sermon, preaching at the interment of my father, for publication which he gave me— Mr Bailey followed me to Mr Whitney’s; and I came back with him. Mr Tyler Bigelow of Watertown had come with him, and left with me a Memorial, in behalf of the daughter of the late General William Hull, claiming payment of his Salary upwards of a year as Governor of the Michigan Territory— Mr Monroe changed his opinion upon this subject— Mr Child came only upon a visit— Deacon Jonathan Bass came to leave an account of his against the Estate of my father; and to enquire about a promissory note from him to my father, which I have not found— He will call again to-morrow Evening. He spoke to me of the tenant upon my Penns Hill Farm, whom I believe to be not a good one— This afternoon all the wearing apparel of my father, excepting a stock-buckle and seven Stocks taken by me, was delivered to my brother—
3. V:30.— Walk—half an hour

After a short walk, awaiting day-light, and the journal of yesterday, I was occupied the whole day and evening, in settling accounts and demands upon my father’s Estate, and in preparing the papers for exhibition to the judge of Probate— Mr Daniel Greenleaf had given me on Saturday an estimate of a reasonable rent for this farm—separate from the House and Garden— Deacon Savil, Josiah and Ebenr Adams have also made one which the latter gave me this day.— Ellis and Brown came out to solicit a remission of a penalty, incurred by a British vessel at Philadelphia, Captain M’Leod, for bringing more passengers than are allowed by Law— I had written on the 20th. of September a Letter to the Secretary of the Treasury on the subject, which I read to them, and with which they were satisfied— Mr Marston had called with Dr Wadsworth of Bristol, Rhode-Island, who came to solicit for his father the appointment of Light-House keeper at Warwick neck— I promised to give due consideration to the application, if the appointment was not already made— I gave directions to Mr Turner to make a suit of Clothes for Mr Whitney the Minister, and told him that my Son George would pay his bill on account of the Executors of my father’s Will— Mr. John Mills Brown came with papers relating to a Patent steering Mill of his Invention, which he wished me to examine— He said he had written to me about it last May, and sent me a Model, which he wished to have examined by the Commissioners of the Navy.— He will come to me again at Boston next Friday— I settled Accounts with Deacon Savil, and paid him for his management of the farm this year according to his agreement with my father— Mr Foster called only, as having attended a Meeting of the Directors of Neponset Bridge. Mr Felt of Hamilton, made a short evening visit; and Deacon Bass, came and settled his note, which I had found, and his account against my fathers Estate— For the excess of the Note beyond the account he gave me a new note to the Executors— My Son John came out from Boston, about Noon, and returned in the Evening, much and very effectively engaged in the interval, assisting me in the settlement of accounts, and preparation of papers for the judge of Probate— Although there is nothing very complicated in this Administration, yet in the number of accounts connected with the sales we find it difficult to keep them all in exact order— I agreed with my brother for his occupying this House till the first of April next. Began a Memorandum for George.
4. V.— Dedham probate Court.— Quincy.

Mr Quincy came out at eleven— We executed and acknowledged before my brother ten Instruments Four Deeds from the Executors to me— Three of them of the Lands on parchment, and one of the two Pews and the Tomb, on paper— One Bond four mortgages from me to the Executors, and a Power of Attorney to Josiah Quincy to act for me, irrevocable as to any action or suit against me upon the Bond and mortgages— We signed also a general Account of Administration, two separate Accounts of Expenditures, and my particular Account with the Executors. Also Letters to Mrs de Wint and Mrs Johnson of Utica, W. S. Smith and J. A. Smith, informing them of the amount assigned to each of them under the devises in their favour. Mr Quincy dined with us and immediately after dinner we rode to Dedham. My brother also went there upon business of his own. He laid before the judge all the Accounts, and exhibited to him all the vouchers for which he enquired, and which were chiefly the Accounts of the several Sales. After examining them he returned to me all the vouchers, retaining only the four Accounts signed by the Executors— The Deeds were likewise all exhibited to him, and he made some question as to the conveyances being to and from myself, in my individual capacity, and as Executor, but did not insist upon the objection— He said he supposed other Deeds might be executed if found necessary; and he did not think Mr Quincy could make the conveyances alone— He administered to Mr Quincy and me the Oath that the account we had rendered was just and true— I presented the additional inventory of 3. Acres of the Quincy lot estimated by the appraisers, which he took; and the list of Books divided between my brother and me and of which I have taken his half at his own apprizement approved by the appraisers— The judge said it would not be necessary that this should be returned to him at all as a part of the Estate; it having been disposed of conformably to the Will— From the Probate Office we went into the Registry of Deeds, and left there to be recorded the four Deeds of the Executors to me the Bond, two mortgages and Power from me which are to be delivered to and kept by Mr Quincy—and he took the two Mortgages of Estates in Boston, to be recorded there— We called on Mr Dowse, and saw him his wife and her Sister Mrs Shaw— Mr Dowse is much out of health— Mr Quincy returned this Evening from Dedham to Boston, and I with my brother to Quincy— Mr. Marston his daughters and Ann Harrod were here in the Evening. My Son John came out from Boston this morning, and returned before we came back from Dedham—

I went with my Son George this morning, and met Coll. Perkins at the Railway, according to my engagement with him last Friday. We walked with him down towards the landing as far as the works had been so completed that we could go over them; and then up to the ledge. We passed the spot where they were digging the cellar of two Stone houses which the company are about to build, for the workmen occupied at the ledge, and which Perkins told me would be finished in a Month from this time— We saw the model of the Bunker Hill Monument, which is a long pyramid, to repose upon a platform and deep-laid basement, without pedestal. He shewed us also two of the Cars, to be used for transporting the Stone, the first of which cost 750 dollars and the second not more than 250— This is the first railway constructed in the United States, and if successful will lead to many others— Its consequences are of great importance, and deeply connected with the prosperity of Boston, and of Quincy for this and succeeding ages— My own fortunes, for the remainder of my days, and those of my children, are also implicated in it; and all the purposes upon which my mind retires for relief to the closing years of life are blended with it— We returned home to dinner— In the afternoon, Mr Joseph Smith of Warren, Rhode-Island came, with several introductory Letters, to solicit some change in the Custom-House arrangements at Bristol with which Warren is connected. I recommended an application to the Secretary of the Treasury, and promised to speak to him on the subject— The two Ladies came on a visit to my brother’s wife— Mr Greenleaf came to inform me that the Parish Committee of seven, had a meeting yesterday, and unanimously agreed to report in favour of commencing the erection of the Stone Temple next Spring; and that two years from that time should be fixed for the period when the present Meeting-House shall be taken down. Messrs.Lloyd and Hall came for an afternoon visit— Lloyd profoundly alarmed for the administration at the probable consequences of a recent British Order in Council interdicting the trade between the United States and the British Colonies, as he said, in both Hemispheres, after the first of December next. It is a new trial, through which we are to pass, and the issue of which is with higher powers— I made light of it with Lloyd, and said as the Georgia War was extinct, there must be something to stir the blood of the public, and it might as well be this as anything else— My Son John came out from Boston, and continued the preparations of arrangements for our departure. Louisa C. Smith went with him to her Sister Mrs Foster’s, leaving finally my father’s house in which she has from her childhood resided— I was up with George till Midnight.
6. V:30.— Boston.

I left for the last time the dwelling House of my father, in which he had chiefly resided for nearly forty years; and entirely for the last twenty-five— I left it with an anxious and consoling hope of returning to it as to my own, probably within three short years, and of finding within the means and opportunity of employing the remnant of time allotted to me on earth, in exercises of filial reverence and affection, of usefulness to my children, of benevolence to the neighbourhood of my own and my father’s nativity, and of ultimate improvement to the condition of my Country— To as much of this as may obtain the approbation of higher power, I implore the directing and effecting hand of Providence— For so much of it as may be destined to disappointment, I pray to be prepared and resigned. I was engaged from my rising hour till eleven in packing for departure. My Son George and Mrs Clark came to Boston in the Morning Stage— I have leased the house and garden till the first of April to my brother, and left the farm in charge of Isaac Farrar, to whom I have agreed also to let the farm on lease for three or five years, from that Time— I took leave of my brother and his family, his daughter Elizabeth being yet confined in bed with a fever, and I came with William Pote to Boston. I left my small Trunk at George’s chamber at Dr Welsh’s, and went to Coll. B. T. Pickman’s where my wife came from the Exchange Hotel yesterday— She was riding out, and I immediately afterwards met her with Harriet Welsh in the Carriage— I went to my Son George’s Office, and there found his partner Mr Kinsman, and a Trustee process was served upon me as Executor against W. S. Smith, for the attachment of his portion of my fathers Estate— I then attended at the U.S. Branch Bank, and executed with Mr Quincy the transfer of 6 per Cents from the Executors to me; and I made drafts on the Branch at Washington for the discharge of my own current expenses— Thence I went to the Exchange Hotel, and discharged all the bills to be paid before my departure— Farrar brought into town five blue chests numbered 1. 2. 3. 4. and 6. with the initials of my name on them containing the papers and Letters-Books of my father and mother with many of my own; which were all deposited at the Branch Bank for preservation— I called then at the Mutual Fire Insurance Office, and effected the Insurance on my Houses at Quincy, and agreed for the endorsement of the mortgages upon my policies on the houses in Court Street, and at the Corner of Nassau Street— A revolutionary soldier named Onesimus Newell called on me at the Hotel. I dined with John Welles; called in the Evening at James H. Foster’s, where I found Louisa C. Smith; & Mrs Clarke, and took leave of them— Then at Dr Welsh’s; and finally came to pass the Night at Coll. B. T. Pickman’s, where my wife was. My Son George, and Smith passed the Evening there.
7. IV:45. From Boston to Princeton— Mr Boylston’s.

I rose before daylight, and from Coll. Pickman’s House went to Dr Welsh’s where at George’s chamber I completed my preparations for departure. At six Divall came with his Hack and William Pote. We took a light breakfast with Harriet Welsh, and took leave of the Alderman Thomas. The Doctor himself is at Wiscasset— We started just after Sun rise, my Son George being with me, and John remaining to go with his mother next week. We came by the same road that we had travelled about this time last year, and as then, breakfasted at Stratton’s in Watertown, and dined at Holman’s in Bolton— We had the most beautiful weather all day, and reached Mr Boylston’s House just at Sunset— Found him in comfortable health and very cheerful Spirits, and had a pleasant evening with him— The day had passed almost imperceptibly in conversation with my Son George, upon my own future purposes and upon his prospects. The decease of my father, and the arrangements which I have been making for the execution of his Will, have formed a new and important aera in my life— It behooves me henceforward to devote the remainder of my time to preparations for my own exit from the stage— To this all my thoughts have tended since I last came from Washington; and to this all my anticipations for the future must lean— The co-operation of my Sons is indispensable to the accomplishment of any of my purposes with useful result, and among my earnest wishes, is one that George should soon connect himself judiciously in marriage— The state of his health, which is very indifferent forms for the present a serious obstacle to this project and there may be others in his temper and disposition— Favoured beyond measure as I have been by the smiles of heaven hitherto through life, very few of the blessings I have enjoyed, have been owing to any foresight of mine— Almost all my schemes have been disconcerted—and the great favours I have received have been unexpected, and with little or no agency of my own— Of these profuse bounties of Providence, it were presumption even to ask the continuance— From public life I have little left to hope, and nothing upon which to rely— My private duties have become complicated, and require much deliberation; much assistance, and much fortuitous co-operation— All that I am to expect from my children is uncertainty; with a few gleams of hope, and many foretastes of discouragement. George’s health is yet very precarious; his Spirits dejected; his self distrust painfully predominant, and my own anticipations at this crisis of my earthly destiny full of apprehension and of anguish— I commence my return to Washington with an aching Heart— But why art thou cast down my Soul? and why art thou disquieted within me?— Hope thou in him—

I attended morning and afternoon at the Public Worship of the Congregational Church, and heard Mr Clark, their Pastor, in the forenoon from 1. Peter 1.8. “Whom, having not seen, ye love; in whom though now ye see him not, yet believing, ye rejoice with joy unspeakable and full of glory.” It was their Communion day; and the discourse was an urgent and animated exhortation to Christian heads of families to join in full communion with the Church— Members of other Churches in regular standing were invited to remain and partake of the Communion which I did. The ceremony was altogether similar to that of the last Sunday at Mr Whitney’s, though rather longer— The communicants were not so many— I walked from the Church to Mr Boylston’s and very soon returned to the afternoon’s service— The text was from Galatians 4:18. But it is “good to be zealously affected, always in a good thing.” The subject was in continuation of the morning’s discourse, and the recommendation of zeal in the Christian cause was urged with all the ardour of sincerity. There was an occasional anthem sung in the Morning, and another in the afternoon; and both times the whole Congregation rose as I entered the Meeting-House, with Mr Boylston— There were three publishments of intentions of marriage—one baptism of a female child, and a notice given of a funeral to-morrow afternoon— We dined at Mr Boylston’s, after all the religious services of the day were over, and Mr Clark the Minister came and spent the Evening with us— Mr Boylston in the course of the day mentioned incidentally that he was born in 1749. His Son, John dined with us, and his grandson Ward, now a lad of eleven years of age, was here by leave of absence from his School in Lancaster. Two other and younger grandchildren were also here this day; a boy of 7 named Thomas, and a girl of five named Alicia. He has one other Grand-child, an infant two years old— He told me he should leave to them his large Estate at this place, and intimated that he should recommend them in some measure to my care or advice for their education— He is to remove on the 20th. of this Month to his place at Jamaica-Plains, Roxbury for the Winter. This mode of life he has now pursued about twelve or fourteen years passing the Summer here, and the Winter at Roxbury— He shewed me this day a plan for a Town Hall which he has had drawn—and for the building of which he has left or intends leaving a bequest— It is also to be used for Mr Clarke’s congregation (only) instead of the meeting-house, in foul weather during the Winter; and Mr Boylston intends that a Tomb should be constructed under it, in which his remains shall be deposited— He remarked upon the similitude of this design, with that which I have formed with reference to my Parents—
9. V:15. Ride to the Sterling Ponds

I wrote till breakfast time, and examined a small stuffed porcupine or hedgehog, which was killed on Saturday, on one of the Hills at the side of Wachusett, or as Mr Boylston now calls it Mount Adams. It weighed about 22 pounds, and was probably not half-grown— Its quills were sharp as needles, but imperfectly hardened into bone. This animal is scarcely known in the neighbourhood, and was a solitary Stray upon the mountains— Mr Boylston bought him for half a dollar of the man who killed him— After breakfast we viewed the Cattle that Mr Boylston and his Son are sending to the Show at Worcester, and then I took a ride with him and my Son George, of about sixteen Miles, round the Ponds in Sterling, which are seen about E.S.E. of the house. The road to them is chiefly the same as that we had travelled in 1821 going to Lancaster; it comes out at the Sterling Meeting house, and the road back is that by which we come from Boston— The Country is covered much with Wood, not very fertile, nor highly cultivated. Yet neither barren, nor neglected— The woods are Oak, Walnut, Chesnut, Maple, White Pine and Birch; none of very large size— We had beautiful weather with the clear autumnal sky— On returning at One O’Clock, I found there had been here a Committee of Citizens of the Town of Worcester— They came again shortly after— Oliver Fiske, my old Classmate, Samuel M. Burnside, and Stephen Salisbury junr, and delivered to me an invitation in behalf of Citizens of the Town of Worcester, to a Public Dinner on Thursday; which with suitable acknowledgments I declined— The Committee remained to dine with us; and Mr Burnside gave me a Letter from Governor Lincoln, containing for myself and my family a friendly invitation to his House while I remain at Worcester, which I accepted— Mr Clark the Minister also dined here, but retired at three to attend the funeral of a child. The Committee remained an hour later, and took a Moonlight Evening for their return home. Mr and Mrs Clarke were here again in the Evening, and Mr John Irving— I had less time for writing than I desired, and the cold North western breeze which came up yesterday morning, and continues, has brought me the unwelcome visit of a sharp Lumbago. I had a couple of handfulls of chesnuts gathered to take with me, to be planted at Washington, and part of them to be taken by George and planted at Quincy. I took a warm draught on going this Evening to bed.
10. V:30. From Princeton to Worcester.

Morning till eleven employed in writing. Mr Boylston accompanied me to Worcester. I came with him in his Chariot, and George alone in my Carriage. We drove immediately to Governor Lincoln’s house— Mr Boylston however returned this Evening to Princeton— The Supreme Judicial Court of the Commonwealth are in Session here; and there was a party of 25 at dinner— Mrs Lincoln, and a Mrs Seaver, wife of her brother were the only Ladies— Chief Justice Parker, the judges Putnam, Wilde and MortonDr Bancroft, Mr John Welles of Boston, and several persons of distinction from the town and County, formed the Company. I had great satisfaction in meeting my Classmates Putnam and Fiske. In the evening we went by invitation to a Meeting of the Society of Odd Fellows—An Association of the members of the Bar, convivial and Literary, who have assumed that title with a view to infuse wit and humour into their proceedings. The Meeting was at Stockwell’s Tavern— There was an Oration by a Mr Barton, a Supper, and a Poem afterwards by Lincoln a brother of the Governor— The Oration was cheerful, but grave— The poem in irregular verse was gay and humorous— The proceedings of the Society were of the same character— They elected an Orator and a Poet for the next Anniversary which is to be in April next, for they have several Anniversaries every year— The Poet declined the task assigned to him; which he said the Society knew he had done before. But he repeated the Offer, which he had made of writing every alternate line of a Poem, if brother Burnside would write the corresponding line— They had elected Dr Mitchell of New-York an honorary member of the Society, and shewed a Letter of acceptance from him commencing with a hieroglyphic representation of Oddity. symbols There was a gigantic Jews harp on the table, and the figure of an owl, with glass eyes, and a label suspended to its bill, with the inscription—And while we are merry, let’s be wise. Captain Symmes was proposed and unanimously elected an honorary member of the Society—and several very odd Resolutions were offered, respecting his projected settlement in the interior of the Earth. A reconsideration of one Resolution was offered; but the President declared it to be a standing Rule of the Society never to reconsider anything. After two or three Toasts succeeding the Supper had been given, at about eleven O’Clock I retired with Governor Lincoln, and came to lodge at his house.
11. VI. Worcester Cattle Show.

The morning began with a ploughing match, by which a field, near the meeting house, of an eighth of an acre was ploughed up. There were nine ploughs, five or six of them with two yoke of oxen, a ploughman and a driver, the rest with one yoke of oxen each, a ploughman, and no driver— The ground was divided into equal parts, and the work was performed in about half an hour— The premium was obtained by one of the single teams; and the object of the match was to ascertain the comparative efficacy of single and double yokes, with and without a driver, and also the comparative merit of the ploughs of different construction with and without a wheel and a coulter— The issue of this experiment was favourable to the simple plough, and the single team— After this we returned to the Governor’s, and thence went in procession to the Meeting House, where after an address read by Governor Lincoln, as President of the Agricultural Society, and an excellent prayer by a Minister of some neighbouring Town, named Nelson, an Oration was delivered by Mr Washburn, well written, well delivered, and well received— The Governor announced in his address that the President of the United States, The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States Commonwealth, Isaac Parker, the judges Putnam, Wilde and Morton, Admiral Sir Isaac Coffin, and some others had been this morning elected honorary members of the Agricultural Society of Worcester County— We then visited and perambulated the penns in which the Cattle were enclosed— There were several hundreds of very fine oxen, bulls, cows and calves. The largest ox, weighing 2450 pounds. Very few Merino Sheep, in no wise remarkable; a Show of swine not more distinguished, one large and handsome Saddle Horse, and one Dray-horse of English breed, imported by Sir Isaac Coffin, and now with a colt. At the invitation of Mr Bigelow the Clerk of the Supreme Court, we stopped and took a collation at his house; viewing at the same time the draught match of oxen, one yoke to a Cart drawing up hill a weight of lb 5000. Thence we returned to the Governor’s, and marched again in procession to the town Hall, to a dinner of about 120 persons— After dinner, were merry and pointed toasts, not too numerous, and mine with a return of my thanks was “the Dairies, Nurseries and Schools of the town and County of Worcester; replenishment to and from them all[”]— We viewed the Show of manufactures which was small—that of butter and cheese, indifferent— Then heard the reports of the Committee, awarding the premiums— Attended at 7. in the Evening an Oratorio at the Meeting House, and heard much of Handel’s sublimity and the Star of Bethlehem, sung by Miss Kimberley. At ten I returned to the Governor’s and retired— He, his family, and George went to a Ball, from which they returned at 2. A.M.
12. VI. From Worcester to Providence.

We took leave of Governor and Mrs Lincoln at 7 this morning, and came seven Miles to Grafton, where we breakfasted. It was the same house at which I had dined when passing from Princeton to Providence with John Boylston the 6th. of October 1823. but not kept by the same man— The name of the present keeper is Baker. We found here Mr Dexter who introduced himself to me as a Son of Dr. Aaron Dexter, and his wife, as a daughter of my old friend T. C. Amory now deceased. They gave the room in which they were at breakfast up to us— He told me he had arrived last Evening, and had come to reside at Grafton, as the Agent of a company at Boston, who were establishing here a manufacture of flax— From Grafton we proceeded through Uxbridge to Slatersville, where we dined— The keeper of this house, named Anderson would receive nothing for our Entertainment— The place looks less thriving than it did last year, some of the buildings having since that time been destroyed by fire— There is nevertheless a large stone house which we visited, and where we saw three hundred spindles of a cotton factory in full operation— There is also another stone building of the same or large size now erecting— The spindles, and the modes of picking, combing, and spinning into yarn the cotton wool, are the same as those I had seen in Russia and at Ghent. The attendance on the spindles, is all by girls— After dinner we came 17. Miles to Providence, and took our lodgings at Blake’s, or the Franklin house— We arrived just before dusk, and found here Mr William Payne and his wife, who had just arrived from Newport, on their return to Boston, and with whom I spent pleasantly part of the Evening. Governor Lincoln had requested my Son George, to write to him by the first mail, the substance of the few words with which I introduced my toast at yesterday’s dinner. George wrote them this evening at my dictation— I said that in returning thanks to the company for the honour they had done me by the preceding toast, I availed myself of the opportunity to add my further thanks for the invitation of the Trustees of the Agricultural Society of Worcester County, to attend at this commemoration, and for the further honour they had done me by electing me an honorary member of the Society— That a large portion of my life had been past, in absence from my native state—an absence which would almost always have been involuntary but for the consideration that it was in the service of the Country. That I had nevertheless from my earliest years heard much of the town and County of Worcester— Of their farms, of their farmers, and especially of their Schools— That to such Instructions as those, the results of which we were witnessing if I could contribute nothing else, they should at least have the tribute of my best wishes—and in that Spirit gave the toast— George wrote also by my direction to J. Binns at Philadelphia, saying I expected to be there next Monday the 16th.
13. V. From Providence to Newport.

Heavy Rain almost the whole Night— We Breakfasted with Mr and Mrs Payne, and taking leave of them about nine A.M. proceeded by Land to Newport. I had only one morning visitant at Providence, General Barton, an old Revolutionary Officer— We came through Warren and Bristol two miles South of which is a ferry— It blew a heavy gale, and we effected the passage of the ferry with some difficulty and danger. The ferryman thought they could not manage the horse-boat, and came over for us, with the Sail-boat. To this, my Coachman, Timothy Divoll, was very unwilling to trust his horses— But there was no other alternative, and into the Sail-boat they went— About the middle of the passage, the waves ran high; the wind blew a tempest— The boat was tossed up till one of the horses lost his centre of gravity. His hind feet were tripped up, and he came down upon his hams— In his fright he recovered himself by a violent effort, and then reared up with a struggle to plunge over the side of the boat— Divoll who held him by the bridle had just strength enough to bring him down again upon his feet, when his hind legs again gave way, and he recovered himself by a second violent struggle; fortunately the boat had in the mean time got over the middle of the river into smoother water, and we effected the passage, without calamitous accident; but I had not for many Months; perhaps for years been in such imminent danger; and for our preservation from it I arrived with suitable impressions, on the other shore; reflecting upon what a slender thread human life depends, and how incessantly it needs the guardian care of superior power— From Portsmouth, on the South side of the river we came to Newport, over a beautiful, and well cultivated Country, and alighted between 3 and 4 in the afternoon— Mr Pearce member of the House of Representatives of the United States had sent me a messenger with information that they had taken Townsend’s house, for me during my stay at Newport— The messenger met me two or three miles out from the Town. Mr Pearce was waiting at the door of Townsend’s house to receive me— Mr Asher Robbins the Senator soon after came in, and after dinner there were a succession of visitors, till late in the Evening— Among the rest Mr William Vernon, my fellow Voyager to France in February and March 1778. and whom I had not seen since the year 1783, when we met in London, but which he had forgotten— Mr Christopher Grant Champlin also called, whom I had known as a student at Cambridge in 1786. and had not since seen—and Christopher Ellery, Collector of the Port with whom I sat in the Senate of the United States in 1807. Coll. Totten, in command here; Lieutenant Governor Collins, and many others.
14. V:15. To Fort Adams. Revenue Cutter Vigilant— John Cahoone

The gale continued, all this Morning, and the Steam-boat Fulton, which should have passed up yesterday afternoon from New-York to Providence, made not her appearance— In her regular course she should have left Providence at 3 this afternoon returning to New-York, and my arrangements were made for embarking in her as she would touch at Newport about Sunset. Disappointed in this expectation I had a prospect of being detained two or three days; but the Revenue Cutter Vigilant was here; and her Captain Cahoone, and the Collector, Ellery, urged me to take passage in her: to which from the necessity of the case I assented— But my Son George being yet unwell, and the weather threatening a boisterous passage to New-York I advised him to return, with the Carriage which had brought us from Boston— He left me accordingly about 8. O’Clock, immediately after breakfast; intending to go this day to Trenton, and to reach Boston tomorrow. After he was gone I received a succession of visitors and with Messrs.Robbins, Pearce, Collins, the late Governor Gibbs, and a Captain Northam, I visited the public Library, a very neat small building of simple but elegant architecture, containing about 2500 volumes— The State-house in which the Legislature meet when assembled at Newport— A newly established manufacture of lace, where I found sixty or seventy young women and girls at work— They had sent a present of a Cap to my wife, and I took for her a Lady’s dress, which had been exhibited at a Show of manufactures last week— We called also at the houses of the late Governor Gibbs; of the present Lieutenant Governor Collins, and of Mr Vernon, who has a valuable collection of Paintings, by some of the celebrated Masters of the Italian and Flemish Schools. At 11. according to appointment with Coll. Totten, I crossed the harbour in a boat and was shewn by him, the works of the fortifications commenced at Fort Adams. The plan of which appeared to me excellent. I had not time to visit Fort Wolcott though invited by Major Mason the Officer commanding there— We returned from the works at Brenton’s Point, in Carriages, by Land, and I received numerous visitors till about 3. when I sat down with a company of about 50 persons to a dinner to which I had been informally invited— I called in at the Bedchamber of old Mr Townsend father of the present keeper of the house now upwards of 80 years of age, and paralytic, bedridden: but who remembered that I had been at his house 37. years ago in 1789— After a short but jovial dinner, I embarked in the Cutter with Mr Ellery, Mr Collins and Captain Northam, and at 5 in the afternoon, we were underway— At the same time the Sky became clear and the Sea Smooth— The Evening was fair, with a light breeze, and we passed the Steam-Boat Fulton, off Point Judith.
15. VI. Passage down the Sound— Hell Gate.

lg.l: — simul alba nautis
Stella refulsit
Defluit saxis agitatus humor;
Concidunt venti, fugiuntque nubes;
Et minax (quod sic voluere) ponto
Unda recumbit.

div.p: these admirable lines of Horace’s ode to Augustus—12 of Book 1. are quoted with almost equal beauty in one of Burke’s speeches— I was impressively reminded of them last Evening as we sailed round point Judith, and passed by Fisher’s Island, and entered the Sound, almost without being sensible that we were afloat. The contrast between the Tempest which the wave had threatened, and the recumbent quiet of the deep, we are witnessing led me to reflections and hopes, that I was willing to indulge, and suitable to the day. On rising this morning I found the vessel was off New-Haven, sailing about seven miles an hour, with a very light but favorable breeze. The Sun rose in Splendor, and introduced one of our fairest autumnal days. It continued until noon; soon after which we had reached the entrance of the East river at Sands’s point— It then fell nearly calm. The tide turned against us, and it was eight in the Evening when we came to the passage of Hell-gate— The Captain sent on shore for a Pilot who came on board, but declined taking the vessel through the passage and we anchored for the night— I was thus disappointed of my intention to reach New-York this day and have lost one day in the progress of my Journey, to Washington— But my companions are social and the Captain very obliging, and we have had good though simple fare, four times in the course of the day— The Captain has also a few books such as Josephus, Pope, Sterne, Burns, Helvetius on Man, the Laws of the United States, and Bowditch’s Complete Navigator. I spent the day therefore without weariness, conversing occasionally with my fellow passengers, observing the villages and steeples as we passed along the Connecticut, and Long-Island Shores, and upon the East-river, and the numerous coasting vessels sailing up and down the Sound; of which there were never less than twenty in sight; and skimming on the surface of Captain Cahoone’s Library— I passed from the Wars of the Jews, to Pope’s Eloisa—and from Pope to the life of Burns which at last riveted my attention— And I read how the ploughman bard was ruined and destroyed by his greatness—the Wreck of his own fame. Passing from the Cottage to the tables and Castles of the great and wealthy, and sinking from contented poverty, into luxury, discontent, habitual drunkenness, and untimely death.
16— VI. Steam Boat Linnaeus from Flushing. New-York.

There was rain in the Night, and the wind this morning was against the Cutter for proceeding to New-York. The tide would not make in her favour for the passage through Hell-gate before ten O’Clock, and there was no prospect of her reaching New-York before noon— Captain Cahoone therefore sent his Boat, and afterwards went in her himself to engage the Steam-boat Linnaeus from Flushing, to stop and take me on board. Half an hour after the boat was gone, the Steam-boat Fulton passed by us on her way to New-York: she had been up to Providence, and returned from thence, since we passed her, Saturday Evening, off Point Judith. Captain Bunker came on board the Cutter, and invited me to go in to the Fulton, which I declined, because having sent to ask a passage, in the Linnaeus, I would not take the chance of disappointing her Captain, should he in consequence of my application come out of his way to take me up— One of his passengers in the first instance objected to the delay of stopping for me; fearing to lose the chance of forwarding Letters by the Packet for Liverpool which was to sail at ten— Captain Peck therefore refused to stay for me; and, was proceeding on his way, when his passenger relented, and he came round for me— I took leave of Captain Cahoone with thanks, and went on board the Linnaeus, with Messrs.Ellery, Collins and Northam. We landed at New-York about ten; and I walked to the City Hotel, where those Gentlemen took leave of me— I made compensation to Captain Cahoone, for the expenses incident to my passage with him, and for the trouble given to his crew; but Captain Peck of the Linnaeus refused to take any thing— I found on board the Linnaeus Mr. Aspinwall of New-York, who informed me he had a dividend to pay on the Estate of Robert Bird and Co. He came and paid it to me at the City Hotel—901. dollars 95 Cents—which belong to the Estate of my father. I found my wife and my Son John at the City Hotel— They had come all the way from Boston, by Land, and arrived here on Saturday— I concluded to remain here till to-morrow Morning, and had a continual stream of visitors, the whole day. Genl. Van Rensselaer, and Mr Ingersoll of Connecticut were the first— Thompson the Collector, Blunt, C. King, Trumbull, G. Sullivan, Morton, Chauncey, Pendleton, M’Cormick, Mumford, Browere, and many others—with an application for the appointment of Peter Stagg as Surveyor— I sent to ask to see Judge Thompson, but he was ill in bed— I missed of seeing Mr. Lawrence, the Secretary of the Legation to England, he having embarked for Liverpool this morning in the Packet. Mrs De Wint, and her daughter Caroline were also here— I called in the Evening at Mr Browere’s house, and saw his Busts with no pleasure. Mrs Adams and John went to the Theatre. I wrote to George and to Mr Quincy.
17. V. From New-York to Philadelphia—

Though I rose as the Clock struck five, I barely succeeded to get on board the Steam-boat Thistle, Captain Jenkins, at the moment when she was about leaving the wharf. The passage to Philadelphia was divided into three equal parts of four hours each—Steamboat from New-York, to New Brunswick four hours, from six to ten— Then Carriage from Brunswick to Trenton—from ten to two— Steamboat Trenton, from two to six, when she arrived at Philadelphia— I found on board the Steamboat Mr Gibbes of South-Carolina, with his wife, a daughter of Mr Oliver of Baltimore, and his brother— A Captain Read, also of South-Carolina, with his Son, a beautiful boy in his eleventh year, but weighing 132 pounds— A giant-like child. I took the whole Carriage to Trenton, and they rode with me— We breakfasted in the first, and dined in the second Steam-boat— Here also I met Captain Renshaw of the Navy, now commanding at the Navy-Yard in Philadelphia. On landing at the wharf, there was a great crowd of People assembled. And among them were John Vaughan, and De Grand— There was also a Coach and four horses at the wharf, sent by I know not whom to take me up; but I declined riding, and walked to the Mansion House. J. Sergeant, R. Peters junr. and C. C. Biddle came in immediately after my arrival, and a number of other visitors in the course of the Evening—among them was Mr Hopkinson— There was much talk of the result of the recent Elections in New-Jersey and Pennsylvania— In Jersey the tickets were avowedly administration and Jackson tickets, the former of which has been successful beyond their most sangwine expectations; having throughout the State a majority of upwards of 4000 votes. The majority for the Jackson Electors two years ago having been about 1000. This change has been the most consoling and encouraging event that has yet occurred— They boasted of a similar change in Pennsylvania, but it is not manifested by the issue of the elections here. Sergeant himself was a Candidate here; and lost the Election by an equal vote 1597. with his principal competitor Horn—A third federal Candidate taking off several hundred of Sergeant’s votes. There is positive loss in Pennsylvania, and those who call themselves the friends of the Administration have neither concert nor courage— De Grand came a second time with a Mr Adams, son of Thomas Adams, heretofore one of the Editors of the Boston Chronicle, who has solicited, and now again solicits an appointment for his brother of Consul at Alicante in Spain. Sergeant made some enquiries, respecting the time, and mode of his departure upon his mission to the Congress now transferred from Panama to Tucubaya near Mexico. He concluded to go on in a few days to Washington— He proposed also to call upon me to-morrow Morning with J. Binns.
18. VI. From Philadelphia to Newcastle— Frenchtown— Baltimore

I wrote an hour this Morning, before breakfast; an achievement which traveling in this Country I almost always might, but seldom do accomplish. Sergeant and Binns came at 8. Sergeant immediately left us, and while I was breakfasting Mr Binns gave me his opinions with regard to the expediency or necessity of removing the Collector of the Port, Steele, and the Postmaster Richard Bache— Steele being disabled by the state of his health from performing the duties of his office, and Bache disqualified by his vices, especially habitual intemperance—and both unfriendly to the Administration— I observed to Mr Binns, that the appointment and removal of Postmasters was dependent upon the Postmaster General, and that having after long deliberation, and not without much hesitation renominated last winter the Surveyor of the Port Glentworth, on whom the principal negligence was chargeable, which had occasioned the losses in the case of Edward Thomson’s teas, it was now too late to remove the Collector upon that ground, and there would be some hardship in displacing him upon the score of his bodily infirmities alone. Binns did not press the point relating to the Collector; but complained that all the subordinate appointments in the Custom-House were of persons hostile to the Administration, and said he had transmitted to the Postmaster General, a formal complaint against the Postmaster. He shewed me a Letter from himself to Mr Markley written last May, and which Markley did not receive till late in August; which he attributed to malversation in the Post-Office; and he declared that Letters to and from him were frequently treated in the same manner or worse. Mrs Binns had also a package from Mr Seidel, principal of the Moravian School at Bethlehem, with some embroidery of the young Ladies, a present for Mrs Adams—which I at first engaged to take with me; but it was found too delicate to travel by the Stage, and was left to be sent round by water— I had almost a crowd of visitors from breakfast time, until half past eleven, when I left the Mansion house to embark in the Steam boat Delaware, Captain Whelden. A Dr. Richardson of Charleston S.C— A Neapolitan Marquis, Citizen of and exile from Mexico, who gave me two of his books and would have told me his Story, if there had been time— Professor G. Tucker, Wallenstein, T. H. Williams & judge Tait, Captain Feed of the British Navy, Sir Isaac CoffinThe Mayor of the City, Mr Glentworth the Surveyor, Mr Bache, Dr Moore, the Officers of the Mint, and many others. Sergeant, Vaughan and De Grand accompanied me to the boat— I stopped at the U.S. Bank, and took an order on the Cashier of the Branch at Boston, for the 901. dollars 95 Cents which I had received in Branch Bills of Mr Aspinwall at New-York—which order the President N. Biddle, readily gave me. Captain Wadsworth of the Navy was in the Steamboat, and rode with me from Newcastle to Frenchtown. He left me there to go to Havre de Grace, and I embarked in the Steamboat United States, Captain Trippe, at eight in the Evening; for Baltimore.
19.— From Baltimore to Washington— Wirt’s Eulogy—

We came down the Delaware river yesterday against wind and tide, and Captain Whelden, from indulgence to a crowd of people who pressed into the Boat, for a sight, left the wharf nearly half an hour after his time. It was thus past five when we reached Newcastle—past eight when we came to Frenchtown, and half past three this morning when we landed at Baltimore— In the boat from Philadelphia I met besides Captain Wadsworth, an acquaintance in Mr Bradford the Printer: (who named to me Miss Sprugel of Salem, New-Jersey) but among the Passengers from Frenchtown, there was not one known to me— An incident which I scarcely remember to have happened to me in a Steamboat before— I found my Son Charles, with my Carriage and Horses at Baltimore, and stopping at Barnum’s new and splendid Inn, only time enough for Pomphrey the Coachman to bring up the Carriage, just after the Clock struck five we departed; and without stopping to breakfast, but barely watering at Merrill’s, and at Ross’s, arrived at Washington, a few minutes before eleven— Within the entrance of the City I was met by Mr Ringgold, the Marshal, who informed me, that the procession which had formed in front of the President’s House was already on its way to the Capitol; but said that if I wished to go home, and take some refreshment the performances would be delayed until I could return— I preferred going immediately to the Capitol. I found Mr Wirt there, and a numerous assemblage of Ladies— The foreign Ministers all soon afterwards came in— The City procession arrived about Noon— Messrs.Clay, Rush, Barbour and Southard, the Postmaster General M’Lean, Generals BrownScott, Macomb, Jesup, Commodores Bainbridge and Morris, and the other principal Officers of the Government, civil and military were there. The Chaplains of the last Congress, Dr. Staughton and Mr Post, occupied the Speaker’s Chair. Mr Wirt spoke, from the Seat of the Clerk of the House— There was a Dirge of Instrumental Music, but no introductory prayer— Mr Wirt’s discourse, chained attention for two hours and a half, with apparent universal approbation. I gave him my special thanks immediately after the dismission of the Meeting by Dr Staughton— I had sent my Carriage and Horses home; and took a Seat with Mr Rush in his Carriage, accompanied by Mr Richard Bland Lee, who told me that he had been charged by the Corporation, with Commodore Tingey, to attend me this day— The Commodore was confined by indisposition to his house— We were escorted by Captain Randolph’s troop of Horse, and they left me at my own door at 3. P—M— I found Johnson Hellen and all the Servants well. Dined at five— But the loss of Sleep, fasting, hurried ride from Baltimore, and crowded meeting at the Capitol gave me a severe headache, which subsided in the course of the Evening— Messrs. Southard, Clay, and J. S. Johnston called, after dinner.
20. VI. Washington— Rain

After a Night of sound repose, I rose this morning entirely refreshed and well— Rose to the cares, and Trials, anxieties and dangers which surround the Station assigned me, and from which I have been for about 100 days partially released— As my day shall be so may be my strength, for action in the performance of duty, and for submission to the Will of Heaven— The visitors of this day came chiefly to welcome my return— The Secretaries of State, the Treasury and War spoke of business in general terms— Mr Barbour after consultation with Mr Clay had written about ten days since to Mr Monroe, enquiring if he would accept an appointment as Minister to the Congress of American Nations, transferred from Panama, to Mexico— He had received no answer, and now proposed that he and Mr Southard should go on Sunday to Mr Monroe’s in Loudon, and converse with him upon the proposal—to which I readily agreed. Mr Clay mentioned also the despatches received from Mr Gallatin, shewing a very unpleasant state of our Negotiations with Great-Britain, and a Letter from Genl. P. B. Porter at New-York, indicating the prospect of a difference, between him, and the British Commissioner, under the seventh Article of the Treaty of Ghent, Barclay. I had seen Genl. Porter, and the Agent Delafield at New-York, and had received from them the same information— General Scott and the other Officers who came with him are assembled as a board of Officers, at the invitation of the Secretary of War, to report upon a system of Cavalry tactics, and Artillery Instruction— I delivered to Mr Smith the Letter from the Executors of my father’s Will, informing him that the devise to him was deposited in the U-S. Branch Bank at Boston, and that by my direction it had been arrested by a trustee process to answer for his debts to me, and to others of the family— He said there were judgment creditors who would be entitled to a preference. I told him that would be a matter to be decided upon by the Courts. He then said he had an equitable claim for an offset of his debts to me; which was for compensation for acting as my private Secretary at St. Petersburg; after the Act of Congress under which he was acting as Secretary of Legation. This pretension now after a lapse of sixteen years, first suggested excited my surprize and indignation which I did not suppress. Mr Rush coming in Mr Smith immediately went away— Mr Schnebley was an unsuccessful candidate for Elector of President and Vice-President, at the last Election— Rain the greater part of this day. I attempted after dinner, with Johnson Hellen to walk to Mr Frye’s and Mr T. B. Johnson’s, but we were obliged to turn back after going about half-way.

Rain almost without intermission the whole day. It confined me to the house, but did not interrupt the stream of visitors, the reception of whom forms the occupation of four fifths of my time, and renders long continual attention to any subject of business, public or private, utterly impracticable— Armistead and Branson came with Letters of recommendation, and soliciting commissions in the Marine Corps— Montano was professedly a wandering, Spanish exile, a Soldier of Mina’s, asking charity, but without voucher to his pretension. Mr Marcy, Comptroller of the State of New-York, is here to accomplish if he can the sale to the United States of the fortifications in New-York harbour—erected at the expense of the State— Mr Hammond was charged last winter with this negotiation, which was however not concluded— Mr Clay spoke of the Negotiations with Great-Britain, which are in ill, and threatening Condition— I had read the recent despatches from Mr Gallatin The British Government have assumed the new ground, of refusing to negotiate upon the subject of the Colonial Trade— They have also made a proposal to compromise the Slave indemnity question, by giving £250,000 Sterling, which I desired Mr Clay to authorise Mr Gallatin to accept, after using all reasonable efforts to obtain more— I firmly believe we shall in no other way ultimately obtain any thing— I agreed also that General P. B. Porter should be authorised to consent that the British Commissioner Barclay should refer to his Government, an ultimatum offered by Porter, to fix our Northwestern boundary— Mr Clay mentioned also an application from Baron Stackelberg the Swedish Chargé d’Affaires, for an Audience to deliver a Letter from the King of Sweden, announcing the birth of a Son, to his Son, the Prince Royal. I advised that Baron Stackelberg should be requested to send the Letter to the Department of State— Mr Southard called in the morning and again in the Evening. He agreed to go with Governor Barbour to-morrow to visit Mr Monroe, and converse with him concerning the proposed Mission— I wrote myself to Mr Monroe— My wife with my Son John, arrived this Evening, just as we had sitten down to dinner, from Baltimore; in our own Carriage, which was sent for them yesterday— Jane Winnull is with them; and John Kirk his wife and child had come on yesterday— Kirk was at Hamilton’s, in Boston.
22. V— Sunday.

Governor Barbour, and Mr Southard called this morning, the former having received an answer from Mr Monroe, declining the Mission to the Congress of American Nations, on two grounds— The State of Mrs Monroe’s health; which he thinks will not admit of his leaving her—and the necessity of his remaining at home to retrieve if possible his private affairs— After some conversation, we concluded that Messrs. Barbour and Southard should nevertheless go, and pay their visit to Mr Monroe at Oakhill— So that my own Letter might be delivered to him— Governor Barbour supposed that Mr Monroe upon being informed that no long absence would probably be required of him, might with less inconvenience leave his family; and with regard to his private affairs, he thought this mission, would be an expedient for retrieving them— They accordingly left me to proceed forthwith— I heard the Morning Service, by Mr Little, from Philippians 4:6. “Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God.”— The first part of this Sermon was a vindication of the character of St. Paul, against charges of extravagance and enthusiasm—the last was a commentary, upon the text— In the afternoon I heard Mr Baker, from Numbers 31.8— “Balaam also the son of Beor they slew with the sword.” A sermon, upon that strange, and incomprehensible character of Balaam, the distinguished prophet and wicked man. Mr Hagner and Dr Thornton called between the services— The other names in the margin, are of evening visitors. I mentioned to Mr Frye, the attachment laid by my direction upon the devise to W. S. Smith in the hands of my fathers Executors, and my motives for it: my object being to secure the payment of bona fide debts due to other members of the family, and to apply the sum payable to me, to the support of his family; being determined to receive no part of it for myself. I said that Smith’s conduct to me had been so exceptionable, that I was not disposed to say any thing further to him about it, but I would be glad if he Frye, who holds one of the Notes to be provided for would speak to Smith on the whole subject; which he said he would— I received this day a Letter from George, which relieved me from much concern for his health. His Letter is dated the 16th. and should have arrived here on Friday, or at latest yesterday— He was unwell when he parted from me at Newport, but says his health has been improved by his excursion— Signed 50 blank, and 9 filled up Patents.

This array of visitors absorbed the day, from breakfast till dinner, and company the Evening. Mr Wertz came again to solicit his Commission as a Justice of the Peace, which I told him could not be delivered to him, unless the persons who had remonstrated against his appointment should be convinced they had done him wrong and withdraw their objections: particularly Mr Coyle— Dr Lane is of Mobile, and has a claim for the maintenance of certain captured Slaves, for which I referred him to the Secretary of the Navy. Dr Staughton came to solicit in behalf of Edward Thomson, for his release from prison— Lee is a grandson of a sometime Governor of Maryland—applies for a Commission in the Marine Corps, and brings a recommendation from Charles Carroll of Carrollton— General Bernard told me, that the Board of Engineers had this morning completed their Report upon the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal. They think it practicable, but compute the cost, at twenty two Millions of Dollars— Mr Smith with whom Mr Frye had conversed, declared himself willing to give assignments upon the devise payable to him, for the discharge of his debts and he had drawn the form of an order for the purpose; but as it appeared that the debts would more than absorb the fund, I desired him to make a minute of all the debts that we may determine how the funds may be most properly applied to them. Mr Sergeant arrived from Philadelphia, and has an Apartment with us. The Militia Legion passed in Review before me, in front of the House. The Volunteer companies, looking well; but at least half the Legion, without uniform or arms. I called at Mr Frye’s— Mr Sergeant, Dr Watkins, and Mr Burnley dined with us. The latter is a member of the Council of the Island of Trinidad, and brought me Letters of Introduction from Jeremy Bentham; to whom he was recommended by Mr Hume, who is Burnley’s brother-in-Law—

Mr Rind came to solicit my subscription, to a Newspaper which he proposes to establish at Georgetown; and Mr Myer for a scientific periodical publication in this City— By a long established rule the President never puts his name to subscriptions, and I refer all such applicants who are numerous to my Son. Coll Tayloe who has been these six or seven years an invalid, was so far convalescent as to pay me a Morning visit; and to repeat the solicitation of an appointment as Secretary of Legation, of his Son Edward Thornton Tayloe, now with Mr Poinsett in Mexico, as his private Secretary. The Coll. spoke also of the Washington Races which are to commence to-morrow. But he has no horse to run— Mr Burnley came to take leave, being upon his return to the Island of Trinidad, where by the British interdiction of American Vessels from the first of December next, he apprehends some difficulty in obtaining the means of arriving— Mrs Tuel came with a petition from her husband, confined in prison for assault and battery; but the petition was not sustained by a recommendation from either of the judges, the District Attorney or the Marshal— I took a walk of an hour trans Tiberim, before dinner. Mr Sergeant dined abroad. Mr Southard called in the Evening— Governor Barbour and he returned from Mr Monroe’s at Oakhill part of the way yesterday. Arrived here this Morning. Mr Monroe still declines going to the Congress at Tacubaya; but now solely on the ground of Mrs Monroe’s health— He is persuaded that if he should leave her she would die— Governor Barbour has been quite unwell, while upon this excursion; and they returned in Mr Monroe’s carriage. I received a Letter from my Son George, and wrote to him, and to the Executors of my father’s Will— Less disturbed than usual with visitors, I was more occupied with formal and necessary, but wearisome official duties. Signed orders for the discharge of Margaret Williams and James Nowlan from prison— 200 Blank Mediterranean Passports. 194. Indianapolis Land-Patents— 32 Military and 43. Militia Commissions— I am returning to my customary routine of occupations, but have not yet entered upon the meditations which the important business of the approaching Winter will require— The time for writing approaches; and I look forward with increasing anxiety to it— My journalizing arrears, are at length brought up since the first of last July.

Mrs. Adams was again taken ill and confined to her bed— I had after breakfast a conversation with Mr Sergeant concerning the Mission to Tacubaya, and we agreed that the Sloop of War Hornet, now at Norfolk, should be ordered immediately by round to Philadelphia; and that he and Mr Rochester should embark there about the fifteenth of next Month— In consequence of Mr Monroe’s declining the appointment, I have concluded to postpone the consideration of a Colleague to Sergeant, until the Meeting of Congress— Mr Southard called in shortly afterwards, and said he would despatch the order to the Hornet this day. Pleasonton said there would be three or four keepers of light houses to be appointed in the course of a few days— Mr Clay, spoke of his Correspondence with the Ministers of Great-Britain and the Netherlands. Mr Vaughan has made by order of his Government a proposition for a compromise of the difference between the Commissioners under the 7th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent P. B. Porter and Barclay— They complain also that Genl. Porter declines applying a Rule which would now operate in favour of G. Britain, which had been agreed upon, and applied in favour of the United States. They propose to declare the channel now contested, common to both Nations upon Condition that the Channel at Bernhart’s Island, be declared so too. That was assigned to the United States upon the Report of the Commissioners under the 6th. Article— Mr Clay said he should reply to Mr Vaughan, that the complaint against Genl. Porter would be communicated to him for his answer, and that the proposition for a compromise could scarcely be considered until it shall be ascertained that the Commissioners disagree— The Correspondence with the Dutch Minister is concerning a discriminating duty, in the form of a bounty to their own ships established by the Dutch Government, which forfeits the right of Dutch vessels to be admitted into our Ports upon the same terms with our own, and would seem to require that the Proclamation prescribed by the Act of Congress of 7. Jany. 1824. should be issued— But we thought it might be more prudent to recommend to Congress some Modification of the Act— The Races of this day relieved me from many visitors— The issue of the New-Jersey, and Ohio elections to Congress has been gratifying. It appears that all the friendly members have been re-elected in Ohio.

Todsen was a surgeon in the army; and some months since was cashiered by sentence of a Court Martial— But it was for an Offence not very aggravated, and he complains, that some if not all the Officers of the Court had motives of personal enmity against him by which their decision was influenced— He had made repeated applications to me before I last left the City to be reinstated; but the power was doubtful, and the complaint against the Court-martial could not be admitted without proof— He now said he had sent documents to the War Department, upon which he wished for a decision— Major Vandeventer brought me two more records of Courts Martial upon Officers in the Army with Sentences of dismission— Hamilton, brought an old claim of his rejected by the Secretary of War, but which he requested me to revise— I called before dinner at Governor Barbour’s house, where is confined to his bed with a high fever. He was unwell before he went last Sunday for Oakhill. He rode thither nevertheless on horseback—but was extremely ill that Night, and obliged to return to the City the succeeding days in Mr Monroe’s Carriage. Dr Lovell whom I met there said he was now a little better— I had Company to dine Messrs.Clay. Rush. Southard, M’lean P.M.G. Anderson and Cutts, Comptrollers, Graham, Johnston, and his brother, Bouligny and his Son. J. Sergeant, Generals Brown, Cadwalader, Daniels, Jesup, Macomb, and Scott, Commodores Bainbridge and Morris, Colls.Cutler, Eustis, Henderson, Jones, Roberdeau, and Taylor; General Marsy, the Comptroller of the State of New-York, Major Nourse, and Lieutenants Tone and Vinton— Governor Barbour, Mr Wirt, Generals Bernard, & Sumner. Coll. Gibson, Mr Aikin and Mr Burnley were invited, but could not come— I spoke to Mr M’lean, of the complaints against R. Bache the Postmaster at Philadelphia; but he said there was nothing proved against him upon which the removal of him could be justified. He mentioned a new complaint by De Grand, as of no consequence, and unreasonable— I wrote to General La Fayette— The race of this day was said to have been very interesting— Mr Sergeant concluded to leave the City early to-morrow Morning on his return to Philadelphia— I signed yesterday 237. Blank Mediterranean Passports, and 194 Detroit Land grants—and this day 85 Marietta. 67. Crawfordsville, and 5 Military and United brethren Land-grants.

Mr Sergeant departed early this morning for Philadelphia— Mr Janney is an Agent for the House of March in the Island of Madeira, and came with a Bill of Exchange for a Pipe and half pipe of wine, which I ordered last November; and the pipe of which was delivered here the day before yesterday, and the half pipe last June. I took for consideration the question of a further order— M’Lean is a young man to whom about three years since I gave Letters upon his going to Cambridge to enter the University at an advanced stage of study. He was graduated at the last Commencement, and came now to thank me for the Letters I had given him— Mr Reid is from New-York, and was Captain of the privateer General Armstrong, which fought a gallant fight in the last War— This was the third day of the races, and Mrs. Adams was so far recovered as to go upon the ground. It was a beautiful autumnal day— I walked an hour before dinner, and called at Govr Barbour’s house to enquire how he was: and heard from a Servant that he was better. But on returning home, I found that Mr Clay had called while I was out. To avoid interruptions of business, I must resume my practice of the last winter, and take my exercise for the day, in a morning’s walk of an hour before Sunrise— I have not yet seriously commenced upon the business of the Winter, but it is before me, and must be speedily undertaken. Since my return here, I have scarcely put pen to paper, except on this Journal, and to sign Land-grants, Patents, Mediterranean Passports and Commissions— I this day signed of Land grants. 45. Palestine. 19. Delaware, 15. Crawfordsville 15 Huntsville 10. Shawneetown 12. St. Stephens 9. Tallahassee. 8. Kaskaskia. and 1. Virginia Military— I began also the perusal of the proceedings of the Court Martial, in the case of Lieutenant Constantine Smith— The papers are voluminous, and were sent to me at Quincy from the Navy Department. I attempted to read them there but could not accomplish the task. I found indeed that there were questions of principle involved in the trial upon which I should chuse not to decide without consultation with the Secretary of the Navy. I could not get through the papers this Evening—
28. V:30. Walk before Sunrise, round the Capitol Square.

Last day of the races— Rainy— I resumed the practice of walking before breakfast, and passing all the remainder of the day at home. Dr Sewall spoke in terms of encouragement of the prospects for the payment of the debts of the Columbian College— But Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General on Thursday was not so sangwine. Dr Sewall informed me that the Law School would open the week after next. Mr Clay spoke of various subjects relating to our foreign affairs— Mr Ironside brought over the proclamation of the Treaty with Guatemala, the ratifications of which were exchanged there, and which has been just received— Those of the Treaty with Denmark, have also been received and the Proclamation issued the 14th. instt. a few days before my return here. The ratifications having been exchanged at Copenhagen. I desired Mr Clay to make a minute of the Subjects which would require notice in the annual message to Congress, connected with the Department of State— He spoke of the strong representations by which I have been urged to remove the principal Custom-house Officers at Philadelphia and at Charleston S.C— They are no doubt hostile to the Administration, and the Collectors use all the influence of their Offices, against us by the appointment of subordinate officers of the same stamp, against us. They alledge therefore that the friends of the Administration have to contend not only against their enemies but against the administration itself, which leaves its power in the hands of its own enemies, to be wielded against its friends— There is no doubt some justice in these allegations, but no positive act of hostility is proved against the Collectors— Steele at Philadelphia, from the state of his health has for more than a year been unable to perform his duty— Swift the surveyor at New-York is under indictment for a conspiracy to cheat, and the jury were discharged, as not being able to agree upon their verdict—eight of them being for conviction and four for acquittal. I think it best to wait some time longer, before making any removals, and I see yet no reason sufficient to justify a departure from the principle with which I entered upon the Administration, of removing no public Officer, for merely preferring another Candidate for the Presidency— I finished this day the reading of the proceedings of the Court-Martial upon Lieutenant Constantine Smith of the Marine Corps, and was not satisfied with them. I passed too much of the day in reading, and not enough in writing. Much of the Evening wasted— Mrs. Adams again very unwell, and confined to her chamber—
29. V:30. Sunday.

Heard this Morning Mr Little, from Genesis 4:26. “And to Seth, to him also there was born a Son; and he called his name Enos: then began men to call upon the name of the Lord.” The last clause of the verse was that upon which the preacher chiefly commented: observing that there was little information attainable of the religious observances, or indeed of the general condition of the primitive inhabitants of the Earth— That there could be little of their history worth knowing as they themselves could know very little— That the account of them given by Moses, was probably a translation from prior hieroglyphics into alphabetical writing: and that it was not pretended by Moses to have been delivered to him by inspiration— That the six days of creation, were not perhaps natural days of 24 hours, but stages of progress in succession— These and other observations somewhat desultory led ultimately to the doctrine in which all Mr Little’s discourses terminate; the right of private judgment, and religious freedom— He noticed the recent decease of the widow of John Law, at the age of 30, and four years after her husband— I called after the service at Governor Barbour’s, and learnt from a Servant that he was much better— In the afternoon I heard a young man at Mr Baker’s, from Luke 16.25. “But Abraham said, Son, remember that thou in thy life time, receivedst thy good things and likewise Lazarus evil things: but now he is comforted, and thou art tormented.” There was much ingenuity, and a good portion of eloquence in this Sermon, the main argument of which was to shew from the emphatic word in the text, “remember,” that the principal if not all the punishment of the reprobate, in the world to come, consists in the reproaches of their memory. The recollection of their own evil deeds— The stings of their own consciences. This is no Calvinistic common place of atonement and regeneration. The topics were well-managed, and fervently urged— A thunder shower came up just at the close of the service, which detained me at the Meeting house, half an hour after it was over, and through which I finally walked home— Mrs Adams continues unwell; confined to her chamber— I received a Letter from my Son George at Boston, who has returned seriously, and I would hope successfully to business— I finished writing the draft of a decision upon the proceedings of the Court Martial for the Trial of Lieutenant Constantine Smith; and I read several despatches from John Williams, Chargé d’Affaires to the federation of Central America, or Guatemala. My time is yet absorbed, leaving much unwritten which I ought to write; and much arrear of reading which is procrastinated from day to day.
30. V:15. Circum capitoline walk.— Sun rose 6:48.

This is my fathers birth day and the Sonnet here enclosed is the meditation of my Morning’s walk. I record it thus that it may be legible only to myself, or to a reader who will take the trouble to pick it out of the short-hand— If it were better poetry I would have written it at full-length— Of my visitors Devoe, was a poor man who lost both his arms by an explosion in firing a gun of celebration upon some fourth of July— He came to shew me an arm with an iron hand of his own invention, the fingers of which he is able to use; Mr Swann informed me that Mr Rush’sSon who was ill with a bilious fever died yesterday, and was buried this Morning. Mr Clay mentioned several despatches received from Mr Gallatin, with a provoking note from G. Canning. Mr Clay had prepared an instruction to Mr Gallatin, refering to a proposition expected from the British Government; upon which I suggested to him, some modification of his draft— The proposition is one of their new school of liberality, seemingly fair, but operative altogether in their favour. I thought it better without absolutely rejecting it, to meet it with a proposition of more enlarged liberality and real reciprocity— Mr Clay brought me the Letter from the king of Sweden, announcing the birth of his grandson, which Baron Stackelberg finally sent to the Department of State— Mr Munroe, the Postmaster renewed a recommendation of a young man, named Kelty, for some Clerkship in a Department— Tayloe is recently from Troy in New-York and going to Virginia— I commenced reading the proceedings of an army Court-martial upon Lieutenant Harrison; gave an order for the discharge of Elijah Shay from prison; wrote to my Son George, and began the Draft of a Message to Congress.

lg.l: Day of my fathers birth. I hail thee yet
What though his body moulders in the grave
Yet shall not death the immortal soul enslave.
The Sun is not extinct. His orb has sett
And where on Earth’s wide ball shall man be met
While time shall run but from thy spirit brave
Shall learn to grasp the boon his maker gave
And spurn the terror of a tyrants threat.
Who but shall learn that Freedom is the prize
Man still is bound to rescue or maintain.
That Natures God commands the Slave to rise
And on the oppressor’s head to break his chain
Roll, years of promise, rapidly roll round
Till not a Slave shall on this earth be found.

div.p: The President
31. IV:15. Walk round Capitol Square— Sun rose 6:49.

General Brown came chiefly to recommend J. A. Dix, for an appointment as Chargé d’Affaires in some part of Europe— Naples, or Denmark for example— The General had sent me yesterday a Letter from Dix to him indicating his wishes to that effect with Letters of recommendation—one particularly from Coll. M. Willett— Genl. Brown had also sent me a Letter from a Mr Stearns, soliciting a Consular appointment in the Island of Cuba— And he also speculated as usual upon the vagarious politics of New-York— D. Brent came about the discontinuance of a prosecution against an Indian for the murder of another Indian at Detroit in the Territory of Michigan. The Secretary of the Territory in the absence of the Governor, asks for Instructions and recommends a noli prosequi—to which I assented. Mr Southard had the proof sheets to correct of Mr Wirt’s obituary Notice, as Wirt himself styles it, of T. Jefferson and J. Adams— I advised the change of the Title to that of a Discourse— And I also advised a Note at the passage which seems to glance in censure at Webster’s conjectural introduction of Speeches for and against the Declaration of Independence— I returned to Mr Southard the proceedings of the Court Martial, upon the trial of Lieutenant Constantine Smith, with my draft of a decision, requesting him if he concurred with me in the principle, to mark any passage where he should think alterations proper. Mr Brent of Louisiana called for a visit— Much gratified at his re-election, and at the issue of the Elections in New-Jersey and Ohio. Major Hamilton came for an answer upon the papers he had left with me. They were claims upon which there had been three years since a decision against him, and which I told him I had not I thought the power to open for revision— A man named Josiah Flagg from Martinsburg Virginia came to see and talk with me— He said he was born in Massachusetts near Boston, but had lived from the age of two years in Virginia as a farmer. He gave me an account of his family, particularly of his three Sons who he said would do well, if they did not take to dissipation— He appears an honest, and pious man.

Day— I am resuming my habits of the last Winter— Since my return, rising irregularly from four to seven— Walking four miles to return and see the Sun rise from my North-eastern window. Breakfast at nine dine at five P—M—and in the intervals, receive visitors, write Letters or drafts of official papers; and read despatches, proceedings of Courts Martial, and Newspapers till ten in the Evening when I retire to bed—
